raw_text:
Prince crowned 'top music earner'
 
 Prince earned more than any other pop star in 2004, beating artists such Madonna and Elton John in US magazine Rolling Stone's annual list.
 
 The singer banked $56.5m (£30.4m) from concerts, album and publishing sales with his Musicology tour and album. He kept Madonna in second place, as she earned $54.9m (£29.5m) while embarking on her global Re-Invention Tour. Veterans Simon and Garfunkel were in 10th place, their comeback tour helping them earn $24.9m (£13.4m) last year.
 
 "Prince returned to centre stage after a decade in the commercial wilderness," the magazine reported. The singer's 2004 tour took $90.3m (£48.5m) in ticket sales and he sold 1.9 million copies of his latest album Musicology.
 
 Although she grossed more than Prince last year, Madonna remained in second place because of the "monumental" production costs of her tour. Heavy metal band Metallica's Madly in Anger with the World tour helped push their 2004 earnings up to $43.1m (£23.1m). They were ahead of Sir Elton John, who took fourth place and almost $42.7m (£23m) from performances including a debut on the Las Vegas Strip. Other seasoned performers in the list included Rod Stewart, whose sold-out shows and third volume of The Great American Songbook covers album helped net him £35m (£19m). The highest-ranking rap act in the list was 50 Cent, who at number 19 took $24m (£13m) to the bank.
llama3.2:1b: Prince earned over $56.5m from concerts, tours, and album sales.
He topped the US magazine Rolling Stone's annual list as the top music earner, ahead of Madonna ($54.9m).
Prince returned to centre stage after a decade in commercial limbo with his Musicology tour and album selling 1.9 million copies, while Metallica's Madly in Anger with the World tour earned $43.1m.

Other notable performers on the list included Rod Stewart and 50 Cent.

He won awards for selling lots of music CDs and tickets, while Madonna, whose songs were on top of the list, got second place by spending more money on her tour.
Simon and Garfunkel's band played their biggest ever shows, but they didn't do as well as Prince in 2004.
Led Zeppelin's third album helped them make even more money than Madonna did last year.
Other singers like Rod Stewart, Eminem, and Drake also made a lot of money on tours.

Madonna was second with $54.9m from her Re-Invention Tour, while Simon & Garfunkel ranked tenth earning $24.9m from their comeback tour.
Prince's Musicology tour generated $90.3m in ticket sales.
Madonna remained second due to significant production costs for her tours.
Metallica ranked fourth with $43.1m from their Madly In Anger With The World tour.
Sir Elton John was fifth earning almost $42.7m.
Veteran performers like Rod Stewart and Bob Dylan also featured, while rapper 50 Cent earned the highest amount of all rap acts at $24m.

The singer, Prince, earned over $56.5 million from concerts, album sales, tour sales, and publishing.
He returned to the top after a decade with his Musicology tour and album.
Although Madonna was in second place due to the cost of production, the singer's 2004 tour helped net him about $90.3 million in ticket sales.
He sold over one billion copies of his latest album, Musicology.
smollm:1.7b: The top music earner in 2004 was Prince, who earned more than any other pop star in the US magazine Rolling Stone's annual list.
He earned more than Madonna and Elton John combined, beating them both by a significant margin.
The singer banked $56.5 million (£30.4 million) from concerts, album and publishing sales with his Musicology tour and album.
He kept Madonna in second place, as she earned $54.9 million (£29.5 million).

The "monumental" production costs of Prince's 2004 tour helped push their earnings up to $43.1 million (£23.1 million), while heavy metal band Metallica's Madly in Anger with the World tour helped push their earnings up to $42.7 million (£23.1 million).
Other seasoned performers in the list included Rod Stewart, whose sold-out shows and third volume of The Great American Songbook covers album helped net him £35 million (£19 million).
The highest-ranking rap act in the list was 50 Cent, who at number 19 took $24 million (£13 million) to the bank.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Prince earned a significant amount for 2004 with a total of $56.5 million from concerts, albums, and publishing sales.
Madonna secured second place at $54.9 million due to her high production costs during her tour.
Simon and Garfunkel were in 10th place, contributing less than Madonna's earnings last year.

tinyllama:1.1b: Prince earned more than any other pop star in 2004, with over $57 million from concerts, album sales, and publishing royalties, according to Rolling Stone's annual list.
He beat out Madonna and Elton John in the U.S. Magazine's ranking of the top music earners.
Prince's tour, Musicology, was a hit, helping him gross $90 million in ticket sales alone.
His album, which features songs from his upcoming album 20/20, also performed well on the charts, reaching number three and selling more than one million copies worldwide.
However, heavy metal band Metalica's tour helped push them to fourth place, with $43 million in earnings from their Madly in Angers With the World tour.
Other notable performers in the top 20 list included Rod Stewart, whose sold-out concerts and third volume of The Great American Songbook covers album brought him over $35 million in gross profits.
Rapper 50 Cent was also a prominent performer, earning nearly $24 million for his fifth studio album, which hit number 19 on the Billboard 200 chart.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Prince claimed the title of top music earner for the second consecutive year with a record-breaking earning from his Musicology tour and album.

With a staggering $56.5 million in revenue from concerts, albums, and publishing sales, Prince outbanked his rivals by $5.4 million over Madonna's second place earnings in Rolling Stone's annual list.
Simon and Garfunkel came in 10th place, with their comeback tour contributing to their own earnings of $24.9 million, while Simon himself grossed $8.3 million from his tours alone.
Madonna's annual earnings include the significant costs of her Madly in Anger with the World tour, which helped push up her earnings by $43.1 million over last year.

Meanwhile, Metallica and Sir Elton John maintained their positions in the top five, thanks to a massive production cost increase that contributed to their record-breaking earnings of nearly $42 million from performances like the Las Vegas Strip debut.
Other notable performers in the list include Rod Stewart with his sold-out shows and third volume of The Great American Songbook covers album, which helped him generate $35 million for the year.
Fifty Cent came in at number 19 with a record-breaking earning of $24 million to the bank, thanks to his success in rap music.

Heavy metal band Metallica contributed to their earnings of $1m."
granite3.1-dense:2b: In 2004, Prince topped the list of top-earning pop stars, earning $56.5 million from concerts, album sales, and publishing, thanks to his Musicology tour and album.
Madonna came in second with $54.9 million, despite her global Re-Invention Tour's significant costs.
Other notable earners included Simon & Garfunkel (10th, $24.9 million), Metallica ($43.1 million), Sir Elton John ($42.7 million), and Rod Stewart ($35 million).
Prince's return to prominence after a decade was highlighted, as his 2004 tour generated $90.3 million in ticket sales, and he sold 1.9 million albums of Musicology.
